newsitem.title: USA: Lockheed Martin gives DEC-Microsoft mail contract.
newsitem.headline: Lockheed Martin gives DEC-Microsoft mail contract.

text.p: Digital Equipment Corp and Microsoft Corp said on Tuesday that they won a $13 million multiyear contract from Lockheed Martin Corp to provide a corporate-wide mail messaging system.

DEC, as the prime contractor will receive $8 million from the deal which calls for installation to be complete by 1998 and servicing to run through 2001. Microsoft, as the subcontractor, will get $5 million, said DEC spokesman Peter Ward.

"Following Lockheed's merger with Martin Marietta and acquisition of Loral Corp, the company faced a mix of mail systems with no common high-speed backbone," said Joseph Cleveland, president, Lockheed Martin Enterprise Information Systems. "The new system will significantly reduce both our administrative costs and message delivery times."

DEC vice president Sri Srikanth said in a telephone interview that the Lockheed contract "is the proof point that this alliance with Microsoft is a success." DEC and Microsoft announced the formation of the Alliance for Enterprise Computing last year that would intergrate their technologies.

Srikanth estimated the current market for mail messaging systems is $1.7 billion and is expected to grow to $6 billion over the next three years as companies with different messaging systems continue to merge and be acquired.
"We're going to be playing very, very aggressively in this marketplace," Srikanth said, adding the problem of having differing messaging sytems is not limited to either the public or private sectors.
"It is not really a very industry specific problem that our customers are facing. It's really any large customer who has a big communications network on multiple systems."
